ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Otitis Media with Effusion (Right Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Unilateral moderate hearing loss, Type B tympanogram with normal canal volume, and elevated wideband reflectance are classic signs of middle ear fluid. History of frequent colds supports this.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Conductive Hearing Loss (Right Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Evidenced by the air-conduction thresholds (PTA 47 dB HL) and middle ear dysfunction; likely secondary to the effusion.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cerumen Impaction
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient history notes excessive cerumen buildup, though normal ear canal volume (0.80 cm3) on tympanometry makes full occlusion less likely than effusion.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To visually inspect the ear canal for cerumen and the tympanic membrane for fluid lines, bubbles, or retraction.
To confirm the conductive nature of the hearing loss by establishing the air-bone gap.
To assess cochlear function; expected to be absent in the right ear due to conductive pathology.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation indicates a unilateral, moderate conductive hearing loss in the right ear consistent with middle ear pathology, likely Otitis Media with Effusion. The left ear is within normal limits.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Type B (flat) with normal volume (0.80 cm3). Left ear: Type A (normal).

tests.name: Wideband Reflectance
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Elevated reflectance (near 100%) in low-to-mid frequencies. Left ear: Normal.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Moderate hearing loss (PTA 47 dB HL). Left ear: Normal hearing (PTA 5 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs align with PTAs. Excellent WRS bilaterally (Right: 96% @ 85 dB HL; Left: 97% @ 40 dB HL).

proposed_items: Referral to Otolaryngologist (ENT) or Pediatrician for medical management of middle ear pathology.
Preferential seating in the classroom (left ear toward the teacher).
Monitor hearing status following medical intervention.
counseling_actions: Explain that the 'flat' tympanogram and hearing test results suggest fluid behind the eardrum is preventing sound from getting through efficiently.
Reassure parents that the nerve of hearing (based on speech scores) appears healthy and the loss is likely temporary/treatable.
Advise on communication strategies, such as getting the child's attention before speaking and reducing background noise.

escalation.rationale_short: Medical management is required to resolve the middle ear effusion and restore hearing thresholds.

follow_up_plan.objective: Re-evaluate hearing thresholds and middle ear status after medical treatment to ensure resolution of the conductive component.

expected_outcome: Resolution of middle ear effusion with medical management (e.g., antibiotics or observation) or surgical intervention (PE tubes).
Return of right ear hearing thresholds to within normal limits.
